Positive: A 45-year-old male patient presents with dark, velvety patches of skin in body folds and creases such as the armpits, groin, and neck. He reports that these patches have become thicker and darker over time. The patient also mentions a history of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes in his family. Upon physical examination, the patient's BMI is above 30, indicating obesity. Laboratory tests reveal elevated blood glucose levels and insulin resistance. Based on these findings, the patient is diagnosed with acanthosis nigricans.
Negative: A 25-year-old female patient presents with dry, scaly patches of skin on her elbows and knees. She reports no family history of diabetes or insulin resistance. Physical examination shows no signs of dark, velvety patches in body folds. Laboratory tests indicate normal blood glucose levels and no insulin resistance. Based on these findings, the patient does not have acanthosis nigricans.
